Hi everyone,

I've been working on a new documentation effort called the GloRuWriClu aka Global Rust Writing Club. It was presented to the ctcft aka Cross Team Collaboration Fun Times meeting on July 19th. @Santiago Pastorino, @rylev and I have been working on applying the framework to the rustc-dev-guide. It's ready to move forward and our target date for a synchronous kickoff meeting over Zoom is September 7th 2021. I'm hoping that many of you will want to join the cohort and increase your knowledge on the workings of rustc while producing some excellent documentation. There will be a sign up form posted on Friday. Here's the plan.

https://hackmd.io/69FQfH3PSOSJA3GHQ-5R2w

Timothy Maloney said:

What is GloRuWriClu?

Global Rust Writing Club - one of the projects planned for "the club" was to produce a updated and new contributor friendly version of the rustc-dev-guide.

I am working on documenting parallel rustc, and am working on adding individual sections for where and how parallelism is used in the compiler to rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/parallel-rustc.

As I am still getting familiar with the compiler's parallelism, I am wondering if anyone has general feedback for how best to structure documenting where and how parallelism occurs.

My current approach is adding individual sections for threads/crates that share state. e.g. if crate A and B share state, and crate C and D share state, then there will be two sections, one describing A & B, the other describing C & D. (sorry if this is a dumb question/example. Still getting familiar with everything.)
